awd_titl_txt: Game Theoretic Modeling for Improved Management of Water and Wastewater Resources Using Equilibrium Programming and Feedback Mechanisms
awd_abstract_narration:
This grant will support the modeling of novel management approaches for improved cooperation among independent water resources users and stakeholders. Such cooperation is not naturally incentivized because the actions beneficial to upstream users can often negatively impact downstream users. These asymmetrical benefits create the potential for non-cooperative behavior in three key areas: 1) water withdrawal rights, 2) water quality responsibilities, and 3) risks associated with flooding. Historically, cooperative agreements among independent entities have required static legal agreements that created barriers to adaptation or policy improvement. This research will explore novel management approaches, such as market-based mechanisms, to overcome these challenges to cooperation. The anticipated efficiency and equity gains in these systems will advance prosperity and welfare for municipal, industrial, and agricultural water users; treatment plant and network operators; and the natural environment. Two contrasting use cases will be considered in this research: urban river restoration in the Anacostia Watershed (Use Case #1) in the metropolitan Washington, DC, area and economic development and ecological preservation in the Duck River Watershed (Use Case #2) in Tennessee. The work will establish new interdisciplinary collaborations between experts in operations research and water resources management, which will promote the progress of science and intellectual merit.

The work will use rigorous mathematical techniques to model deterministic and stochastic water infrastructure systems from a one-level and two-level equilibrium problem perspective based on non-cooperative game theory. The developed models combine engineering, water policy, machine learning, risk analysis, resilience planning and economic elements. The novelty of this work is that it accounts for risk and benefits in a systematic, unified, and endogenous manner across all entities and their interactions and allows the system operator/regulator to effectively balance risk and cost under uncertain and/or changing conditions. Furthermore, it is anticipated that the work will lead to algorithmic advances in decomposition methods for water equilibrium problems as well as stochastic equilibrium models for this general class of infrastructure equilibrium problems. Also, a rolling-horizon, stochastic mathematical program with equilibrium constraints will develop strategic learning algorithms for water stakeholders to improve their decision-making over time.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
PROJECT SUMMARY

We built deterministic and stochastic, water market equilibrium models to better balance upstream and downstream river users' access to water (quantity and quality).  We concentrated on two testbeds:the Duck River in Tennessee (water quantity) and the Anacostia River (Washington, DC. area) (water quality).In addition, we sought to build two-level equilibrium models to understand the tradeoffs between sustainability and technology using water (e.g., desalination) as an example. 

INTELLECTUAL MERIT

PAPER 1

 N.T. Boyd,  S. A. Gabriel, G. Rest, T. Dumm.  “Generalized Nash Equilibrium Models for Asymmetric, Non-cooperative Games on Line Graphs: Application to Water Resource Systems,"Computers and Operations Research, 154, February, 2023.

We produced 2 mixed complementarity problem (MCP) modeling formulations for consumptive-loss reduction markets for rivers to incentivize better use of water resources (water quantity focus) in our first paper.  These models are of the Nash-Cournot, equilibrium type. We also provided theoretical results as well as numerical ones including for the Duck River (Tenn.) testbed for insights.  

PAPER 2


S. Allen, S.A. Gabriel, N.T. Boyd, "Inverse Optimization for Parameterization of Linear Complementarity Problems and for Incentive Design in Markets," (under review at Computers and Operations Research, Spring 2024).

We developed models for inverse optimization/inverse equilibrium problems based on linear complementarity problem (LCP) theory of complementary cones.  The application was then applied to an illustrative river system (from paper 1) to figure out the right level of taxes a water governing agency would need to induce river users towards socially beneficial outcomes.

PAPER 3

 N. Boyd, S.A. Gabriel, K. Brubaker, M. Ries , “Addressing TMDL Challenges in River Systems with a Stochastic, Mixed Complementarity Problem” in review at Environmental Modeling and Software, February, 2024 (submitted May 2024).

In paper 3, we  produced an initial MCP model for a water quality focus with the Anacostia River (Wash. DC) as testbed.  The resulting complementarity problem relies also on meeting TMDL (total maximum daily load) restrictions for the river.  The resulting optmization problems, one for each jurisdiction in the watershed are chanced-constrained (second-order cone) convex optimization problems.  Taking the resulting KKT conditions to each of these problems combined with market-clearing constraints leads to a stochastic linear complementarity problem.

 

PAPER 4

 N.T. Boyd, S.A. Gabriel, “Understanding the Role of Technological Complexity in Water-Resource Transitions using Stochastic, Bi-level Optimization” (submitted May 2024).

This paper examines socio-economic and technology development related to water systems with a focus on desalination in the face of rising demand due to population growth.  The model developed in this paper is a stochastic, bi-level optimization problem.

PAPER 5

S.A. Gabriel, D. Flocco, T. Boomsma, M. Schmidt, M. Lejeune, "Using Difference-of-Convex Functions to Solve Complementarity Problems" (submitted June, 2024).

This paper develops a  novel approach to solve equilibrium problems expressed as mixed complementary problems (MCPs) using the notion of differences of convex functions. We have tested the approach on the stochastic water equilibrium problem (paper 3) and other problems.

BROADER IMPACTS

 2021-2023

8 presentations

 2024  

9. N.T. Boyd, M. Ries, S.A. Gabriel, Kaye Brubaker, Addressing TMDL Challenges in River Systems with a Stochastic, Game-Theoretic Approach. 2024 World Environmental & Water Resources Congress. Milwaukee, WI, May 19-22, 2024.

10. S.A. Gabriel, D.C. Flocco, T.K. Boomsma, M. Schmidt, M.A. Lejeune, A Heuristic for Complementarity Problems Using Difference-of-Convex Functions, 33rd European Conference on Operational Research, Copenhagen, Denmark, (part 1 of 2 combined talks), EURO Conference, Copenhagen, Jun 30-Jul 3, 2024.

11.  S.A. Gabriel, D.C. Flocco, T.K. Boomsma, M. Schmidt, M.A. Lejeune, A Heuristic for Complementarity Problems Using Difference-of-Convex Functions, 33rd European Conference on Operational Research, Copenhagen, Denmark, (part 1 of 2 combined talks), ECSO-CMS Conference, Stockholm, Jul 4-5, 2024.

12. S.A. Gabriel, D. Flocco, T. Boomsma, M. Schmidt, M. Lejeune,  Equilibrium Modeling in Natural Gas Markets: A Theoretical Analysis &  a Case Study for Brazil, A Method for Solving Gas Market & Water Market Equilibrium Problems, International Symposium on Mathematical Programming (ISMP) Montréal, Canada, July 21-26, 2024ISMP Conference, Montreal, Jul 21-26, 2024.

13. N.T. Boyd, K. L. Brubaker, M. Ries, S.A. Gabriel, Reducing Pollution in River Systems using a Stochastic, Game-Theoretic Modeling Approach, AWRA Joint Water Resources Conference 2024, St. Louis, MO, September 30, 2024.

14. N.T. Boyd, Introduction to Chance Constraints Using the Anacostia River Testbed, Petrobras, Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, October 28, 2024.

15. S.A. Gabriel, D.C. Flocco, F.F. Mazzini, D.S. Pinheiro da Silva, M.C. Levorato Junior, E.V. Porto, N.T. Boyd, K.L. Brubaker, M. Ries, T.K. Boomsma, M. Schmidt, M.A. Lejeune, Equilibrium Modeling in Natural Gas Markets: A Theoretical Analysis & a Case Study for Brazil, A Method for Solving Gas Market & Water Market Equilibrium Problems, Trans-Atlantic Infraday Conference, Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, October 31-November 1, 2024.

16. N.T. Boyd, S.A. Gabriel, Understanding the Role of Technological Complexity in Sustainability Transitions Using Stochastic, Bilevel Optimization, Trans-Atlantic Infraday Conference, Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, October 31-November 1, 2024, NSF Award # 2113891.
